p: In Africa, there has been an increase in temperature of c. 1.5°C between 1900 and the 1990s [ 6]. However, the effects of recent and future climate changes on the distribution of tsetse and other vectors, and their associated diseases, remain poorly understood [ 7, 8]. There is disagreement, for example, about whether the resurgence of malaria in the East African highlands in the 1990s was caused by rising temperatures or by increasing levels of drug resistance and decreasing control efforts [ 9– 13]. Resolution of the debate is made more complex by the apparent absence of data on changes in vector population levels and biting rates.
